climbs.name: Why Me?
climbs.fa: Ken Trout, Brian Ferguson, a long time ago

content.description:
Why Me? ascends a fairly clean, bolted slab climbing past 5 bolts that ends under a roof crack.

Rappel from here, but it needs an updated rappel anchor.... I am unsure if the roof crack that very obviously splits the dome in half has been done.
content.protection: A standard rack to #3 and 6 draws.
content.location: It is the bolted line going dead center up the middle of the dome, under the very obvious crack.

content.description: Sloe Moe is a nice, 2 pitch route up the left side of Little Wigwam Dome. Start up a flake (crux), then continue up the slab clipping 2 bolts to a belay stance. The second pitch takes easy 5.7 cracks to the summit.
content.protection: Singles to #1, extra #2-#3, and a small handful of quickdraws.
content.location: It ascends the leftmost slab on Little Wigwam Dome.

content.description: Climb the chimney with the beautiful, splitter fingercrack inside until the chimney shuts and spits you out onto the mossy slab. Eventually join up with a right-angling, grassy and mossy crack. This will get better when it cleans up... if that ever happens.
content.protection: 0.3-3 C4 cams, a wirebrush, and some safety goggles.
content.location:
It ascends the dihedral opposite of "

The Haunted Mansion

".... They both end on the same anchor.

content.description:
The Haunted Mansion climbs a really awesome, varied crack in a corner. It is mostly offwidth with a few fist jams and slowly widens into a squeeze chimney near the top, and when it does, the angle lessens to where you can leave the chimney and traverse a few feet left into a fingercrack. Alternatively, climb straight up the slab from the squeeze.

You can lieback this; however, the rock is oddly slippery, so it is much more insecure.

There is a large boulder up high in the squeeze. It moves, and I tried really hard to get it out. It doesn't really get in the way or anything, so just tread carefully.
content.protection: #3-6, with a finger sized piece or two; and doubles in the #4 to #5 range. Take a BD #7 and #8 if you aren't comfortable with easy squeeze chimney.
content.location: On the far climber's left hand side of the dome, there is a piece of the dome that split off and is slowly making its way into the river - head towards this. On the slab above the route, there are SS anchors you can rappel from and into the little alcove.

content.description:
This is a fun moderate that is more interesting and much taller than it first appears. The rock is generally very good once you get a few feet above the ground. The wall faces west/WNW and sees afternoon sun.

Climb the short seam past a bolt and a small stopper (~#4) to a small shelf below the slab. Climb the slab on amazing crimps, past 4 more bolts, to the top and an anchor.

Note: there is an anchor above the diagonal cracks to the right. I'm unaware of the history of these climbs and only discovered the anchor upon topping out this line.
content.location: This is not on Little Wigwam proper but close enough to include in this area. It's across Wigwam Creek just upstream from the dome. It will be very obvious across the creek on your right if you approach Little Wigwam from the backside.

climbs.name: Between Two Firs
climbs.fa: Tyler Dziedzina, Greg Miller, bolted on lead, w/ Ellie Moffat

content.description:
This is a unique sporty slab climb on a beautiful piece of granite. Start on a ledge between two pine trees, climbing up and around a flake. From here, gain a pair of horizontal flaring cracks (crux), then climb the balancy arete to the top.

The lower start, an indirect variation, will add two bolts of 5.12- nubbin pinchin', Braille reading, slab climbing.
